HELEN MILLER POST OFFICE BUILDING

    SEC. 117. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Postal Service building located at 550 Fisherman Street in Opa Locka, Florida, shall be known and designated as the `Helen Miller Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the building referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Helen Miller Post Office Building'.

ESSIE SILVA POST OFFICE BUILDING

    SEC. 118. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Postal Service building located at 18690 N.W. 37th Avenue in Carol City, Florida, shall be known and designated as the `Essie Silva Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the building referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Essie Silva Post Office Building'.

ATHALIE RANGE POST OFFICE BUILDING

    SEC. 119. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Postal Service building located at 500 North West 2d Avenue in Miami, Florida, shall be known and designated as the `Athalie Range Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the building referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Athalie Range Post Office Building'.

GARTH REEVES, SR. POST OFFICE BUILDING

    SEC. 120. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Postal Service building located at 995 North West 119th Street in Miami, Florida, shall be known and designated as the `Garth Reeves, Sr. Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the building referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Garth Reeves, Sr. Post Office Building'.

    SEC. 121. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Post Office located at 16250 Highway 603 in Kiln, Mississippi, shall be known and designated as the `Ray J. Favre Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the United States Post Office referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Ray J. Favre Post Office Building'.

    SEC. 122. (a) REDESIGNATION- The building of the United States Postal Service located at 2419 West Monroe Street, in Chicago, Illinois, and known as the Midwest

Post Office Building, shall be known and designated as the `Nancy B. Jefferson Post Office Building'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the building referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Nancy B. Jefferson Post Office Building'.

    SEC. 123. (a) REDESIGNATION- The facility of the United States Postal Service located at 9719 Candelaria Road NE in Albuquerque, New Mexico, and known as the Eldorado Station Post Office, shall be known and designated as the `Steve Schiff Post Office'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the facility referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Steve Schiff Post Office'.

    SEC. 124. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Post Office located at 860 Penniman Avenue in Plymouth, Michigan, shall be known and designated as the `Carl D. Pursell Post Office'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the United States Post Office referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `Carl D. Pursell Post Office'.

    SEC. 125. (a) DESIGNATION- The United States Post Office located at 202 Center Street in Garwood, New Jersey, shall be known and designated as the `James T. Leonard, Sr. Post Office'.

    (b) REFERENCES- Any reference in a law, map, regulation, document, paper, or other record of the United States to the United States Post Office referred to in subsection (a) shall be deemed to be a reference to the `James T. Leonard, Sr. Post Office'.

Prudential Town and Country Real Estate
Direct: 508-655-2155 Phone: 508-655-2155
  
Helen was born and raised in Natick, Massachusetts. She has a deep appreciation and understanding of the Metro West Region, its property values, and knows first hand what a wonderful place it is to work and live in. As a successful entrepreneur in Natick for eleven years, Helen owned and managed a bustling hair salon with six stylists, manicurist and esthetician. Combining her business expertise, and in-depth knowledge of the Metro West Region she is well prepared for the challenges of the real estate profession. Helen brings years of experience, commitment and dedication to her clients with pure enthusiasm.

<body lang=EN-US style='tab-interval:.5in'>

<div class=Section1>

<p class=MsoTitle>BEFORE THE SHORELINES HEARINGS BOARD</p>

<h4><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>I<o:p></o:p></span></h4>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-indent:.5in'>On February 5, 2001, <span class="name" tag_id="0.68277400 1108553928">Helen Miller</span>,
Paul Scheyer, Elfrieda Taylor, John and Jennifer Didio, Betty Haynes and Wes
Henry (ÂCitizensÂ) filed two motions for summary judgment with the Shorelines
Hearings Board (ÂboardÂ).<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span>The first
motion requests the board reverse the City of Bremerton (ÂBremertonÂ) and the
Department of EcologyÂs (ÂEcologyÂ) approval of a shoreline conditional use
permit for a residential development in Bremerton.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">Â  </span>They base their motion on two theories.<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">Â  </span>One, they contend this permit is inconsistent with a prior
decision by Bremerton denying a similar permit application to a property on the
same street as the applicants in this appeal.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â 
</span>Two, they contend the decision violated the public trust.<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span>Both Bremerton and Ecology oppose the
motion, but have not requested affirmative relief themselves.<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â Â  </span></p>

<h4><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>II<o:p></o:p></span></h4>

Cottingham, Judy Wilson, John Bolender and Phyllis Shrauger, reviewed the
pleadings.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span></p>

B. St. Pierre represented Bremerton.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â

</span><![endif]>Is the application adequate under WAC 173-27-180 and the

<p class=MsoNormal style='line-height:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent2>2.<span style='mso-tab-count:1'>Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>Does
this proposal require a shoreline variance permit?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in;line-height:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent2 style='margin-left:1.0in;text-indent:-.5in'>3.<span
style='mso-tab-count:1'>Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>Is this conditional use permit
application consistent with the policies of the SMA and the Bremerton Shoreline
Master Program (ÂBSMPÂ)?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in;line-height:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.5in;line-height:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

yes">Â </span>5.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>Do the
appellants have standing before the board?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><b>VI<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>The first
motion asks the board to reverse the issuance of the shoreline conditional use
permit.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span>It does so based upon: 1) the
public trust doctrine, 2) a letter from Ecology staff, concluding Bremerton
should have processed a shoreline variance permit, rather than a conditional
use permit for alteration of the view corridor criteria of the Bremerton
Shoreline Master Program (ÂBSMPÂ); and 3) BremertonÂs actions regarding another
shoreline permit, which was never appealed to this board.<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span>Ecology does not contend there are disputed
material facts, but argues, as a matter of law, the motion should be
denied.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span>Bremerton, however, essentially
argues both the Citizens have failed to make a prima facie case demonstrating
no disputed facts; but even if it has made such a case, there are disputed
facts.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â Â  </span></p>

<b><span style='font-size:12.0pt;mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

center'><b>VIII<o:p></o:p></b></p>

200%'>The board declines to enter partial summary judgment to the Citizens,

200%'>No other party has moved for summary judgment.<span style="mso-spacerun:

style='mso-tab-count:1'>Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>We understand the Citizens are

1'>Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  </span>The CitizensÂ motions for summary judgment are denied.</p>

style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>The hearing will be shortened to one day, March 19, 2001.<span

200%;mso-list:l22 level1 lfo28;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]>3.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>The Citizens shall immediately schedule an appointment with
Administrative Appeals Judge, Phyllis Macleod, at the boardÂs office in Lacey,

200%;mso-list:l22 level1 lfo28;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]>4.<span

200%;mso-list:l22 level1 lfo28;tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]>6.<span
style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>Each party submitting multiple exhibits, shall place them in a
binder, and submit the original and six copies of them, along with an exhibit
list to the board at the hearing.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â 
</span>Oversize exhibits, to the extent they can be copied and reduced in size,

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent2 style='text-indent:-.5in;line-height:200%;

style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>Each party shall avoid cumulative testimony and exhibits.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent2 style='text-indent:-.5in;line-height:200%;

style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>Testimony shall be factual in nature and not state legal
conclusions.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">Â  </span></p>

style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>                 
</span><![endif]>Evidence, both testimony and exhibits, must be relevant to the

</span></p>

Napier Chat

Re: re:hello

Posted By: Charlie napier <c.napier@napier.abel.co.uk>
Date: Wednesday, 6 October 2004, at 11:33 p.m.

In Response To: Re: re:hello (Helen Miller)

Hi Helen,

Sorry to take so long to get back to you. I can only find three records of Elizabeth Napiers who were born in Fetteresso before 1855: (1) Elizabeth Napier, father James Napier, mother Jane Fairweather, born 05 March 1834; (2) Elizabeth Napier, father Andrew Napier, mother Elizabeth Stewart, born 09 October 1846; (3) Elspet (sometimes used for Elizabeth) Napier, father James Napier, mother Ann Officer, born 08 December 1821.

I cannot find any records of an Elizabeth Napier born in Kincardineshire on either 1813 or 1814, nor can I find an Elizabeth Napier who was born anywhere in Kincardineshire before 1855 who had parents David Napier and Jane Scott. I am sending direct to your e-mail address a list of all Napier births in Fetteresso before 1855 and also all Elizabeth Napiers who were born in Kincardineshire before 1855. I hope these will be of assistance to you. The next thing I would suggest is to try Aberdeenshire. I will see if I can have a look next week.

Yours,

Charlie Napier

July 18, 2003

Generous Sponsor Makes CA Fly!

Funding & Sponsors

A great donation from an anonymous sponsor gives wide and capable anti-gravity wings to a full set of 5 Communication Agents!!!

Today, at approximately 2pm Rome time, a empathetic supporter has contacted me personally to donate Ã¢ÂÂ¬ 6350 (=USD $ 7,170) to support the learning path fee of five Communication Agents applicants that do not have enough funds to cover for their fee.

The generous sponsor has preferred to remain anonymous and to support silently but vigorously this passionate effort.

As Suhit Anantula from India was the only applicant so far listed in our Learning Support Fund queue, he has gained already acceptance and full coverage for his expenses during the first year as a CA.

I urge each one of you, with a serious interest in this Initative to sign-up rapidly as I can only take up a maximum of 5 to 8 individuals at a time. Being a personal coach to each one requires me to reserve enough time and resources to be able to provide the quality service and attention that each one of them deserves.

Stay tuned for more breaking news on new applicants coming onboard in the coming hours!

July 18, 2003 in Funding & Sponsors | Permalink

Frontier Days - our annual parade with a BIG ATV impression
By Bob Fleege
rdfleege@atvscene.com

Approximately 50 members of the Webster County Wheelers showed up to ride in the parade to show our support for the elected officials such as Senator Daryl Beall and House Representative Helen Miller who have gone to bat for us to help us overcome legal issues so we can open a 2,000 + acre OHV Park. It very well could become the biggest ride park in the Mid West!

On the first weekend of June our local community in Fort Dodge, IA (home of the Maxxis 12 Hours of ATV America) holds its annual Frontier Days. Frontier Days is an event that started over 30 years ago as a means to honor our heritage and celebrate the present. This year's Frontier Day Parade was a perfect opportunity for our local club, The Webster County Wheelers, to thank our local House of Representative Helen Miller and our local State Senator Daryl Beall for the excellent job they did for us in this year's legislative session.

The members of the Webster County Wheelers and the Iowa OHV Association have been working hand in hand with the City of Fort Dodge, Webster County, the State of Iowa, the Department of Natural Resources (DNR) and a local group of gypsum manufactures to turn mined out quarries into a huge State OHV Park. Such a task would be a win-win situation for everyone involved and have a tremendous economic impact to the local communities.

However, before we could make this happen we needed a piece of legislation which would remove the gypsum manufactures of any future liability from the land which would be used as an OHV Park. This was a fair enough request on their part taking into account the excessive number of pointless, downright ridiculous law suits these days.

Like every state organization we had a whole list of things we wanted to accomplish in this years legislative session; however, this one took priority and thanks to the dedication and commitment of our local representatives from around the state of Iowa we got the necessary wording to satisfy the requirements of the current land owners, the gypsum companies.

The Iowa OHV Association encouraged all ATVers to send thank you e-mails to their respective representatives and thousands of them did. However, our club wanted to do something extra for Helen and Daryl because, without their efforts leading the way, the bill most likely would have died on the floor along with any hopes of moving forward with our local OHV Park this year.

Here, House of Representative, Helen Miller leads the Webster
County Wheelers in the the yearly Frontier Days parade.

We invited the representatives to lead the Webster County Wheelers in this year's Frontier Day Parade. Our local Kawasaki dealer, Racing Unlimited, Club Car dealership, and R&J Materials, each provided a mule style machine for the representatives to ride. The first vehicle in our group was Bruce Bresser pulling an 8 foot banner with our club local, the Maxxis 12-Hours of ATV America announcement and a list of our local events. Bruce was followed by Representative Miller, as Senator Beall represented both of them on the Dignitary's viewing stand.

Following Representative Miller was 50 plus ATVs, Dirt Bikes and snowmobiles! The site was so impressive that thousands of people stood up and started clapping as we drove by in the parade! As with all of our events, safety was first and all riders were required to wear helmets and most wore riding gear from head to foot, including chest protectors, even though we drove along at snail's pace.

 

At the beginning of the parade, all of the local dignitaries, including the Mayor of Fort Dodge and our local elected officials lead the parade. Behind them was yours truly, Bob Fleege (pictured here), Reed Cooper.

Helen had so much fun she rode back with us and rode through the parade a second time with the Webster County Wheelers.

This is the trailer we use to haul the Maxxis 12 Hours of ATV America Hour/Webster County Wheelers banner with. It brought up the rear of our parade display

 

 

 

 

Local Fort Dodge sign shop - Double M Signs has been a long time supporter of our club. They provided our club with a trailer graphics and a two sided sign listing all of our club events including the Maxxis 12 Hours of ATV America and the Webster
County Wheelers Poker Run to be held the day after the 12 Hours.

Riders ranged from young to old, kids, Mom's, Dad's, teenagers and even a Grandpa and Grandma or two. Everyone had a ball and it was a tribute I know Representative Miller and Senator Beall will never forget and the start of what very well will be the biggest ride park in the Mid West!

THE CLUB

Welcome to the home page of the Geelong Gliding Club Inc.. Established in Victoria, in 1929, Geelong Gliding Club was the first gliding club in Australia. The club was formed as a voluntary non-profit organisation to make available the facilities for, and train interested members of the general public in, the sport of gliding.

Since that time it has operated at a number of sites culminating in the establishment of the soaring centre located at the Bacchus Marsh Airfield, currently shared with two other clubs. This sites offers a variety of soaring conditions including thermal, ridge and wave lift, while remaining within easy reach of Melbourne, Geelong and Ballarat. As well the club operates camps for it’s members for extended periods at various sites around Victoria.

The combined club operation at Bacchus Marsh is the largest in Australia with a total of eighteen club gliders and five tugs. The club owns and operates it's own fleet of training and modern fibreglass dual and single seat gliders. Launching is provided by the club’s tugs, winch or by auto tow.

The club has a number of large hangars available for it’s aircraft ensuring ready availability of aircraft for the use of it’s members. Bunkhouse accommodation and catering facilities are also located on site for the use of all the resident club’s members.

You will find us operating on all weekends, public holidays and most Fridays, weather permitting. Visitors are always welcome.

Oral Histories

  • Courtney Brooks
  • Mabel Burts
  • Mary Child
  • Joseph and Carol Dodd
  • Mabel Lyles
  • Helen Miller
  • Harold Payne
  • Charles Sampson
  • John and Mary Sullivan
  • John Ticer
  • Buster Williams

Courtney Brooks

Although Courtney Brooks worked for the Records Center of the General Accounting Office, his real interests as an adult were in activities that he started in childhood. One was a drummer in the Armstrong High School Band. The other was playing sports in the neighborhood. He played in his own band, the Courtney Brooks All Stars, and others all around the country. In 1946 he started a semi-pro football team, the Alexandria Rams, which was integrated by 1951. A decade later he started a football team for boys coming out of high school. He was also instrumental in starting a baseball league for youth. In all of these, he experience and moved along, the shift from segregation to integration. Today he is still helping his neighbors by volunteering at a food mission, directing the Blues Society, and organizing neighborhood festivals.

Mabel Burts

Mabel Burts has fond memories of her neighborhood around St. Asaph and Franklin Sts. where she was raised by an extended family, including her grandmother who had been a slave. She worked at the torpedo factory and Ft. Belvoir's Army Hospital. She has been very active at her church assisting in many social activities and benefit programs.

-->

Mary Child

Mary Moss Child was born in the early twentieth century and has lived in Alexandria since 1938. She volunteered for the Alexandria Boys and Girls Club and became Personnel director for the City in 1955. The city had about 800 employees, by her estimate, at that time. At first each department offered different benefits. Mrs. Child oversaw benefit restructuring so that they were more equal across the board.

Joseph and Carol Dodd

Joseph Dodd, with help from wife Carol, tells us about growing up on South Royal St Â about his schools, playmates, the neighborhood, and the city market among other things. Together they comment about AlexandriaÂs different neighborhoods, such as Old Town, Del Ray, and Rosemont, throughout the years.

Mabel Lyles

Mabel Lyles spent her early childhood with her mother's family in the rural countryside of Spotsylvania County, VA. She tells stories of washing clothes in the stream there and going to school in a one room schoolhouse. She was able to attend Virginia Union University in Richmond on scholarship and went on to become a teacher. She moved to a segregated Alexandria in 1950 where she taught school and served her church in Christian Education and other activities.

Helen Miller

Helen Miller proudly traces the history of civil rights for African Americans through her own family. Her grandfather, himself the son of a slave owner, was one of the first black residents of Aurora Hills. Her father was a cook at the Capitol and "kept his place" in spite of the many famous people he saw each day. Because of his steady job he was able to buy a house for his family when his children were small. Helen, and many others, marched and participated in sit-ins in order to open libraries, restaurants, banks, and ABC stores to blacks, as customers as well as employees. She marched for city jobs in the Fire, Health, and Police Departments. She pioneered as one of the first black graduates of the Police Academy. Her daughter was one of the first black bank tellers in the City. In addition, she tells us delightful stories about her childhood - swimming in the Potomac, the fire at the Vinegar Factory, and bootleggers during prohibition.

Harold Payne

Harold Payne was born in Alexandria and lived here all his life. His family moved often to different neighborhoods so he has great stories about many different areas of the city. He was a member of the Lions' Club for forty five years.

Charles Sampson

Charles Sampson was born in Alexandria and lived here all his life. He was a member of the fire department from 1937 until his retirement in 1975. As a result, he knew the streets, businesses, and landmarks of Alexandria like the back of his hand. He carefully kept a collection of photos and mementos from his career which he has donated to the Alexandria Library and is now available in its Special Collections.

John and Mary Sullivan

John and Mary Sullivan live in the Del Ray area of Alexandria. John grew up there and Mary has lived there since her marriage in 1946. They describe the businesses and families of their neighborhood, and what it was like for their children in the fifties and sixties as they were growing up. John had a long career with the FBI. Mary was a homemaker, a community and church volunteer, and also held some professional positions. They are a couple who has seen the neighborhood change throughout the years.

John Ticer
John Ticer was born in 1923 in his familyÂs house in Alexandria, and has never lived farther than seven blocks from there. He has lived in his current house for 37 years. Both of his parents also grew up in Alexandria, and while he was growing up here, Mr. TicerÂs father was on the City Council, served as mayor, and had a long career with the railroad. John attended the old Washington School, now the Campagna Center, the old Jefferson School which has been torn down, George Washington High School, and graduated from the University of Virginia. He worked as a soda jerk at Nicklin's Drugstore, served as an enlisted man in World War II, and worked for Westinghouse Electric and Atlantic Research Corporation. He and his wife Patsy have served on the City Council, and Mrs. Ticer is now a senator in the Virginia General Assembly. John continues to have an active interest in AlexandriaÂs history.

Buster Williams

Charles K. (Buster) Williams was born in Alexandria in 1908 and has lived here all his life. He attended elementary school at St. Josephs and Parker Gray, then went to high school in Washington D.C. because there were no secondary schools in the city for African Americans at that time. Some of the jobs that he talks about are hauling ice on an ice cart, boot black at a local barber shop, truck driver and delivery person for Virginia Public Service, working at the White House, and barnstorming as a semi-pro baseball player. He has fond memories of growing up in a small city as a child.

Heldena II  page1  page2  page3  page4  page5  page6  page7  home acbm
Woman to Woman, an interview with Helen Miller
By Bev McMullen
All the players were in place. Rick and Gayle McGraw, owners of Heldena II, Gord Wilson and wife Janet, owners of B-IV, Murray Walker, owner of Clarie II and his girlfriend Pam Blair, and over 200 spectators decked out in straw bowler hats with black Heldena ribbons and racing bandanas. Also present, Helen Miller, the namesake of Heldena II, daughter of Fred Miller, the untouchable Great Lakes Gold Cup winner. All were gathered for the re-launching of Heldena II and a re-creation of the past when boats like these raced each other in the early twenties. History repeating itself.

Helen Miller seemed overwhelmed with the whole shebang but was excited about her first ever ride in her fatherÂs famous ÂBlack BoatÂ. We sat and talked for a few minutes. She told me that she was 8 years old when her father died. She does not remember her father nor does she remember the boat. She told me that her mother never talked about her fatherÂs sudden death at 44 years old at the height of his racing fame. Helen said her father lived a full and incredible life and was an extremely hard worker. He lived hard.

She said nearly 8 decades later she got a phone call Âright out of the blueÂ and agreed to go to Rockwood to Peter BreenÂs ÂbarnÂ as she called it to see for the first time the Heldena II. Helen said she was Âsimply speechlessÂ when all she saw was a skeleton of a boat in a barn and that she ÂcouldnÂt get over the sizeÂ. ÂI went to Peter BreenÂs three times,Â she said, and Âonce to sign the chairs with my name as a souvenir for Rick McGrawÂ. After visiting Peter BreenÂs and reading about the history of the boat, she said, ÂI thought it was unbelievable what young Matt Fairbrass did in finding the boatÂ. ÂI still thought it was shocking to see the enormous size of the boat, to me, it wasnÂt a racer as it was too bigÂ. ÂAfter hearing MattÂs story I just couldnÂt believe what he had done, with the help of Gravenhurst boatbuilder Mike Windsor.Â ÂThen I started to get to know Rick McGraw, at first I was scared and overwhelmed with the whole thing because unlike my father, I live a very quiet and sedate lifestyle. I was nervous at first but when I came to Muskoka with my friends we simply had a wonderful time.Â

ÂTo meÂ, Helen said, Âthe whole story of my fatherÂs boat is unbelievable. After talking for hours to Rick McGraw, he inspired me to reflect back on my charismatic and daring father.Â ÂAt first, I didnÂt like all the hype but when I saw what that couple (the McGrawÂs) did for HeldenaÂs big party, I was truly speechless.Â ÂMy heart pounded when Rick took me down to the water to see the boat, I was overcome with emotion as I could not fathom how Peter Breen put this together and how enormous it lookedÂI was speechlessÂ.

She told me that she was surprised when they brought out a specially designed wooden bridge ramp so that she could walk on her own with dignity into her fatherÂs boat. ÂI think there are only pictures of my rear end when I christened the boat with Champagne, it was starting to become fun and when I was beside Rick in the front seat, I was impressed.Â ÂEverybody was on the boat, Rick, Peter, Matt, Jane, Mary Jean and off we wentÂ. ÂI was real nervous when you (Bev) got up and walked to the end of the bow and took our pictures. You were very braveÂ, said Helen.

ÂWhen I was out in the boat, something happened inside me and I had this great craving to understand everything Rick was telling meÂ Helen said. ÂI started to feel a spark of something that must have been hidden inside me all my lifeÂI want to live another year so that I can drive HeldenaÂ. ÂI didnÂt feel Rick went fast enough, it wasnÂt as fast as I thought it was going to be and it was then that I wanted to driveÂ, she said.

Rick McGraw is reliving Fred MillerÂs dream, and perhaps fulfilling it by taking his daughter, Helen, for her first ride in her namesake, Heldena II. She was very impressed with what was done in honor of her father. Hats off to you Helen, IÂll see you next year behind the wheel of Heldena.

News Archives 2002
Club News | Upcoming Events | Pilot Conversions

CLUB NEWS

East wind and temp inversion again. Cross country flying with some wave over the other side of the Ranges. Lots of people out. The concrete ramp to the front door of the clubhouse has just been poured. Students, Greg S, Stuart McIntyre, Greg O. Nick frys up some lunch sausages. Dave Long does a F&F in OWL and then Terry takes Greg O up in it for some spin practice. Instructors panel meeting, and the Wayne Mackley has some computer lessons.

Helen Miller (21/12/02)

Narrow thermals, east wind and temperature inversion. First GGC flight 11.45. Pie cart car runs out of fuel at south end. Students, Cath, Marcin, Greg O, Simon G, Gavin Grass. VMFG does a cable overrun. Apperance of a Maupin Woostock and a Supergoose. Cath does sausages yet again. Mike Durrant flys to Ararat and back, almost 300 km.

Helen Miller (14/12/02)

Cross country weekend with 200km task. Pik20 outlands at Anakie and Bill aerotows it out. Rolf and Shannon and Dave return early. New members Mike Mees, Greg Savige and Robert Chisholm. Cath does sausages. Terry, Olgy and Toby flying. Big BBQ welcome home for Toby and Rolf.

Helen Miller (7/12/02)

Lots of AEF and F&F flights including a backpacker from Genoa called Anes Ferrari. Anes found us on the internet, and walked from Bacchus Marsh station. Cath & Dave do lunch hotdogs. Mr Ferrari drives the piecart back, very slowly and then John Flanagan explains our tug signals. Anes is taken to get strange fish & chips and then stays the night with a huntsman spider. Sunday busy. Andrew G and Bill with lots of F&F flights. Hans,Olgy, Mike Rawlinson, Kevin Raner, Greg O, and Martin flying. Cath doing sausages. Roy Porter signs up, he got a membership for Fathers Day. Radio not working because aerial has been pulled out. Anes misses the last train and stays another night. Helps crush cans from the piecart.

Helen Miller (1/12/02)

The latest committee decisions:

  1. The costs per minute for all gliders will increase by five (5) cents except the K13 which increases by three (3). Effective December 2nd '02.
  2. Sunscreen will be made available in the pie cart for the use of all members, this service is designed to encourage the members to be aware of and take precautions against the dreaded Aussie skin cancer.
  3. Ian Patching of VMFG has donated his motor vehicle for use with our pie cart and should be hooked up to it by the time you read this. We are then looking at disposing of the excess motor vehicles which we have accumulated.
  4. The committee is looking for members to participate as mentors for new members, if you would like to be involved contact a committee member.
  5. A social sub committee has been formed so if you have some ideas or input talk to Cath Lincoln, Nick Popovich or John Styles.
  6. The cost of a standard AEF is now $85.00 and as part of the package a copy of the GFA video is to be given to the passenger.

Kevin McGowan (25/11/02)

Still flying Janus as an aileron push rod on the K13 was bent during reassembly. Good thermals. Greg and Hans fly to Anakie. Olgy, Frank and Adrian flying. Nick does a second sausage sizzle.

Helen Miller (23/11/02)

Glass in pie cart window with broken catch breaks in wind. Dave takes it away to be reglazed. K13 having its' annual. Greg, Marcin and Mike flying Janus with Norm. Good lift, actually get over the Ranges. Cath and Dave doing sausages for lunch to much aclaim. Fly all four ends.

Helen Miller (16/11/02)

Cap Weekend at Nyah

  • The Rogers and McGowans and Nathan are already at Nyah, and flying. Have to stop because winch axle breaks. (2/11/02)
  • Heinrich with family, taking grandson Josh for a fly. Tim visits in his ambulance. Hans and Greg O. fly Blanik for 1.5 hours, from Nyah to Nyah West, and back again,and again. Irwin on winch. (3/11/02)
  • Shane Till from SGC learning to run winch. Dave Burke ex SGC visits. Trouble with phones. Have to waggle wings to start launch. Martin Power has a cable overrun in GVE, damages landing gear door. (4/11/02)
  • Kim Power does her winch solo in the Swan Hill Blanik. Use parachute and water as ballast. Packing up gliders BACK TO BACCHUS (5/11/02)

Helen Miller

The Wave Camp was a roaring success. There was strong wave every day, and the weather improved each day. Over the few days there were several gold heights. Repeatedly. THAT was easy. And there were at least two Diamonds, possibly more. Ken Secomb got his Diamond with a flight to 19,800'.

Yesterday, Tuesday, was the best day. Arriving at Noelhurst there was a beautiful Foehn gap between Mt William and the airfield, and another just downwind to the east of the airfield, and then another, and another... The gaps stayed there all day, never closing, hardly shifting.

I got my Diamond as well, with a flight yesterday to 24,700' QNH! It wasn't just the hypoxia making me feel euphoric! It's extraordinary looking down at clouds 16,000' below you, seeing them stretch off for hundreds of kilometers. There were plenty of wave clouds down below as well. But it was -30 degrees outside, and my feet were numb. I'd gone through one layer of cirrus, with another one higher to the west. There were ice spicules covering the canopy above me, and most of it was misted except the clearviews.

I was still intermittently getting 3 knots above 24,500', but I was somewhat hypoxic, and didn't want to hunt around for the lift at that altitude. So out came the brakes. It took a long time to get down, and I played around at low altitude for a while. Low altitude being 14,000'.

Melbourne Control gave me the airways clearance. Flight Service quizzed me about what I planned to do once I reached FL 250, whether I'd be hanging around. I don't think other aircraft could hear my transmissions, as one radioed "Melbourne, what sort of aircraft is that?"

What a great camp, and what an amazing flight I had!

Never let it be called the waveless camp again!

David Long - from a GGC News Group post (12/06/02)

If you are a member of a private health fund you may be able to have most of your annual subscription paid for. Bill Johnston, who is with Medibank Private, has Advantage Plus and Advantage Plus Extras. He took his receipt from a club Cash Tin Holder and received $150 in cash towards his annual subscription. A visit to your private health fund may yield useful dividends. Sport is part of healthy living and his health fund sees this as a wise investment.

Bill Johnston (03/06/02)

The Queen's Birthday Long Weekend Wave Camp is on again. Yes, last year there was wave, and in an effort to increase our chance of getting wave this year the camp has been extended to include the Friday. Grampians Soaring Club will again have their tug available at Noelhurst airstrip from the Friday, and meals and basic accommodation will be available at Bastin Park. See the GSC web-site

Brian Woods has offered to be available for aero-tows on the days either side of the camp if the weather forecast is promising for wave. Fancy Gold or Diamond height this year?

If anyone is interested in staying at Bastin Park Thursday night or wants meals on Friday, please let me know so that it can be organised with GSC. I can be contacted on 9852 1849 or via email.

David Long (16/05/2002)

The one hour restriction on flying time of club gliders never was officially imposed by either an AGM or a GGC Committee.

It was a convention driven by shortage of gliders and radios, by the club members of the time and policed by duty instructors when the club had only a Kookaburra an Arrow and a Boomerang. The convention on the Kookaburra was actually half an hour maximum as it was the only two seater.

Nowadays with five single seaters and three two seaters; these restrictions which have lingered on in many minds are simply not relevant and not to be continued.

After discussion at a committee meeting it was agreed that whether a club glider is being used cross country or locally there shall be no restriction on the time the pilot can use the glider excepting the K-13, Puchacz and Junior where common sense has to be exercised. In these cases the pilots concerned can come to an agreement by use of the radio.

It makes no sense for one pilot to cut short their flight so that another pilot can use the glider if there is a serviceable glider in the hangar waiting to be used.

The instructor on duty should be consulted if there appears to be a shortage of ground crew before any other gliders are brought out. Gliders may need to be tied down between flights.

All the single seater excepting the Junior have towing bars and wing walkers to facilitate movement to the launch point, all it needs is you and a car with a tow bar.

GGC Committee (6/4/2002)

Six GGC pilots competed in the Victorian Soaring Association State Competition held at Raywood - Bendigo Gliding Club between 9 and 16 of March 2002

  • Terry Bellair
  • Simon Brown

  • Haidyn Dunn

Congratulations to Heidyn Dunn for his excellent result in winning the VSA State comps. (17/3/2002)

Kim Power took her first solo in the K13 on the 4th of March 2002. To share the excitement with Kim were Mum and Dad, her grandparents from Nyah, little sister Jessica, and several of her friends from within the club and out. Then it was off to school for the afternoon. (6/3/2002)

Eleven GGC pilots participated in "The Very Last Horsham Week" competition:

  • John Ashford - GDH,
  • Terry Bellair - HDE,
  • Simon Brown - GSM,
  • Terry Cubley - GSM,
  • Bill Johnston - UKA,
  • Wayne Mackley and David Long - OUL,

Cathy Lincoln and Tegan Cubley provided much needed crew support. Please follow this link for the competition summary.(13/2/2002)

Congratulations to all those who competed.

Olgy Szemis and Simon Brown are competing at the club class, and several members intend competing at Horsham week and the state comps at Raywood including Jarek Mosiejewski, Olgy Szemis, Bill Johnston, John Ashford, Mark Simpson, Erwin Hiss Wayne Mackley and Dave Long, we wish them well.(8/1/2002)

The usual hot weather at Nyah was missing this year but still many cross country flights as well as badge flights were carried out. Along with cooler weather a smaller than usual group enjoyed a somewhat laid back camp. We started later, often finished earlier and generally had a relaxed time.

Dave Long, Oliver Groholski and Shannon McGowan each attempted silver distance to Sea Lake and return. At the time of writing it appears that Dave's photo's indicate a successful trip, Shannon missed the correct sector and Ollie is yet to have his photo's verified. Also Dave and Ollie attempted their five-hour duration with Ollie missing out by about twenty minutes. All three also are hoping they have achieved gold height during flights at Nyah. Dave and Shannon are getting barographs calibrated as I write. At this time I am unsure as to what is happening to Ollie's barograph as he is away with the family in New Zealand, however there was a problem with the barograph as the drum was not correctly fitted onto the drive and the second half of the flight was not recorded. Something for pilots and observers to look out for. Shannon and Nathan Farrow also managed to get converted into the Std. Jantar and both had several flights and are keen for more.

With the smaller group and less tow bars for trailering several members have done extra "duty" to help with getting things to and from Nyah. Neil Thompson not only took the LS4 to Nyah in the week prior to Christmas, he returned home for new year with the DG300 as it was not needed, returned to the camp on Jan.2nd and at the end of camp took home the Janus FQT and has to go back to Nyah to get his caravan. Martin Power took home the Puchacz with his Nyah "bomb" and will drive it back to pick up the Super Cub and return to Bacchus. On behalf of all I thank these members in particular for their help.(8/1/2002)

Peter Kingston has resigned from the club and as a consequence his role as tug master. Rob Tester has been approached to fill the position of tug master.

Andrew Groholski has volunteered to become treasurer and has been co-opted onto the committee.

As the club is about to change to a new system of accounting, Andrew will not take on the treasurer job until the existing system is up to date, this system was originally devised by John Hampson many years ago and substantially improved by Jeff Farrow when he became treasurer. With all the requirements of this day and age the old system has passed its use by date so a new system is to be introduced. The new system is based on M.Y.O.B. with a "front end" written by a member of V.M.F.G. at no cost to us. V.M.F.G. also use this system successfully so in the longer term we may, with some luck, be able to do a single flight sheet on the field electronically and download it directly into the club computer. This will mean no more tedious entry of flights by the treasurer and no dispute between clubs as to cross charges as both clubs use the same information and quicker entry to member's accounts. To enable all of this to happen the club has purchased a new computer along with the relevant software and it is hoped to start making the transition early 2002.(8/1/2002)

Members will have noticed the large box holding membership and credit payment information usually in the pie cart. For those who have not ventured into it the following will give an insight.

When the box is opened you will see that on the right side of the box is the credit machine attached to a wooden base, also the required slips are in "slots" around the machine and a small notice attached to a block of wood with required information for use at the phone rather than taking the whole box. On the left side lid are the instructions as to how to carry out a credit transaction.

When the lid on the left side is turned, it is held closed by magnets, the information for signing up new members is revealed, attached to the underside. In this half of the box are folders with membership applications, information sheets and certificates for flights of "passengers", also the two books of forms to be used for G.F.A. membership and a copy of the chart as to how the initial payment when joining the club is broken up.

Members should acquaint themselves with the procedures, they are relatively simple, and it may be you that next time is asked by a prospective new member "how do I go about joining the club". For the system to work properly it is also important that all of the contents be returned to the box on completion of any of the transactions and that the box is returned to the clubhouse each night and taken out each morning. If anyone has any questions or suggestions about these procedures please contact me and I will endeavourer to sort out your idea/problem.(18/11/2001)

John Buchanan has taken on the role of membership secretary / coordinator. As part of this job he will be responsible for getting the books to our new members. Whenever a new member is signed up get John if he is at the field and he will pass on the books, if he is not about when I get the membership application via a cash tin holder I will contact him. Note that the books will no longer be available in the workshop as previous but will be under the control of John. (18/11/2001)

A somewhat smaller group traveled to Nyah this year so only two single seat gliders were taken and no tug. Only winch launching being available so the usual out landing checks were not done, but both Heinrich Nowak and Shannon McGowan managed to "solo off the wire" and the others were re-checked and had several more launches, many in the single seaters including the Swan Hill Boomerang, obviously the local Blanik was used for the dual flights.

The other participants in the weekend were Rob Tester, Faye Wilson, John Binney, Martin Power, Doug Rogers, Bill Johnston, Erwin Hiss, Mark Simpson, Mike Durrant and I. On Saturday, Sunday and Monday the weather was typical Nyah, HOT with climbs were up to 8500 feet, Shannon managed 8000 ft on one flight which is the highest he has been in a glider, he was most impressed with this as he was solo at the time. Given that the group was small and we only had the two single seaters no real cross country flights were attempted but some flights to Swan Hill and Balranald and similar places were completed. Because of the smallness of the group it was a fairly relaxed weekend, which was enjoyed by all. As usual Doug's wife Mary kept up the flow of tea and coffee to all and also cooked pies on one day with sausages the next for lunch, Doug should be encouraged to bring Mary with him whenever he comes to Bacchus.

Tuesday dawned overcast, and as we all wanted to get home at a reasonable time it was decided to de-rig our two aircraft and head off home, most leaving by noon. Shannon had one final achievement for the weekend in that he started to learn the ancient art of winch driving and managed a couple of launches from the winch end. I feel sure come one stinking hot day in January he will regret being so keen to learn this art. (14/11/2001)

 

UPCOMING EVENTS

This year Christmas Party will be held on Friday Dec. 7th at Aero's Event Venue above the terminal building at Essendon Airport. The cost of this night is $12.00 per adult with half price for children up to 12 years and under 4 years free. Drinks will be available at bar prices. Finger food will be served.

It has also been arranged with one of the local flight schools to have flights around the city of 20 - 30 minutes for approx. $35 - $ 40 each, the flights to be arranged on the night between flight school and members.

In an attempt to encourage harmony and friendship with our co-clubs at Bacchus both Beaufort and the V.M.F.G have been invited and will be attending.

To ensure your place at this event could you please contact Kevin McGowan by December 1st with numbers attending, also if you could indicate if, and how many are likely to take the flight it would help in arranging aircraft.
The next committee meeting is to be held at the clubhouse on Friday the 16th November at 8pm. See Geelong Gliding Club Activity Calendar 2001 – 2002 for the full list of club events.

About WEA

Below find the WEA Mission Statement, WEA's current Officers and Committees, Member Responsibilities, and the Member Application process.
WEA Mission Statement 

To provide a means for Worcester Executives Association (WEA) members to exchange business information through: internal promotion of their products and services in classification talks; weekly meetings encouraging the exchange of contact information and leads, and by sending a weekly meeting update and lead sheet. The Worcester Executives Association encourages members to work cooperatively to increase the efficiency and profitability of each business in the association.

WEA Member Responsibilities
Involvement is key. To get the full benefit of WEA membership for you and your company, attendance
at regularly scheduled business meetings is important.

However, it is also suggested that you:
Represent your firm with dignity and integrity
Discover and pursue practical ways of assisting other members
Give business information (leads) and act on information received
Provide referrals and contacts to other members
Pay dues on time
Recommend member firms to your own associates, employees, friend, and family
Assist in strengthening the association by serving as an officer or committee head when asked
Seek out qualified new members in open classifications
Member Application Process

Contact the Executive Director (phone number and email and postal addresses below). You should be invited to join by a member, your sponsor, but you may also nominate your own business for membership, if the classification appropriate for your business is open (see Open Classifications). Please note that 60% or more of your revenue must come from business in this classification.

Mark Johnson, Maintenance and Grounds Department
Working in Maintenance and Grounds for Mark Johnson is not just a job, it is a personal commitment to the educational environment of the district.

In typical fashion, one hot day last summer he drove in from his home on a Saturday to fix a broken window at an elementary school so that the school would be safe for students and staff.

Helen Miller, Bus Driver, Transportation Department
Students on Helen Miller's bus do not know the number of their bus - but they know it's “Miss Helen's bus.” They also learn the importance of respect and punctuality. In 32 years of transporting generations of students, Miller is never late.

Parents know that their children are safe on Miller's bus, and she treats her bus as her classroom. And that classroom has included parents and community members each year during the Superintendent's Bus Tour.

Nguyen D. Saari, Interpreting Services, State and Federal Programs Department
An 18-year employee of the district, Nguyen Saari has dedicated herself to serving English Language Learners.

Saari, a refugee from Vietnam after the fall of Saigon, helps families - students, parents, and extended family members - assimilate into their new country and culture, and always does so with compassion.

Deborahann Gilles, Superintendent's Secretary
Deborahann Gilles has worked as the superintendent's secretary since 1984, first for Robert Trigg and now for David Gordon. She has helped both superintendents deal with the district's growth in stature in the community and statewide as the district has grown to the 12th largest in the state.

“She speaks daily to parents, teachers, administrators, citizens, and government elected officials and community leaders. Deb holds each in high regard and makes each one feel as important as the other, said EGCAA President Tom Jenkins. “No matter what unfolds during the day for the organization, Deb keeps her focus on schools and students.”
Frank Lucia, Principal Elk Grove High School
Frank Lucia is one of many people in the district hired by Dr. Arnold Adreani, the principal of Joseph Kerr Middle School. Lucia transferred to Valley High School as a biology teacher when the school opened in 1977, and later became an athletic director, vice principal and finally principal at Valley in 1993. He was appointed principal at Elk Grove High in 1997.

“Frank is well loved by students, teachers, and staff,” said Barbara Fife, his secretary while at Valley. “He has initiated many innovative programs at Valley and Elk Grove schools and gives 100 percent support to the people working to make these programs succeed for our students.”

President's Report:  President Helen Miller began the meeting with introductions and good news from team reps. The Huron High School Women's Tennis Team is the state champion.  This is the first time the Women's Tennis Team has been state champion since 1989. 

Minutes:  Helen Miller asked if everyone had a chance to review the September minutes that were emailed to the general membership and reps.   Upon motion and second the minutes were approved.

Treasurer's Report:  The Treasurer's report was emailed.  If there are any questions please contact Helen Miller or Jill Orizondo.  Two representatives advised that they are not receiving the financial reports.

Committee Reports:  Helen Miller asked for committee reports. 

Bricks.  Toni Aussum Fear reported that the entryway and bricks will need to be removed and the paving redone.  She reported on discussions with her brother and his viewing of the site.  Her brother is donating his services to tear out and replace the bricks. The landscapers are planning improvement in the stadium area near the mulch with a flaming H installed as a gift from the class of 2005.  The new bricks are in storage and the rebuild will begin as soon as they can do it.

Concessions.  Helen Miller reported that with the new turf there are more non-Huron concessions.  A. Orizondo is shopping and purchasing and stocking the concessions.  Helen M. reported on the need to create a plan with a storage solution for concessions activities and Spirit Shop.   There is a need for storage space and transportation.  Helen M. has asked Alan for data so that we can develop proposals to businesses and foundations.  Helen M. reported that it is time to look for infrastructure to operate the concessions.  There was discussion about existing buildings and the need for a storage solution with heat.  Helen M. invited ideas and asked reps to email her with ideas. 

Membership:  Helen Miller reported that membership has brought in a total of $14,308.  This is a 35% increase over last year.  So far 375 families are members.  We will send out more info on members as soon as it is available.  Phonathon:  Toni A. reported on the phonathon.  Each evening two 1-1.5 hour shifts are needed.  The student athletes need to arrive at 5:30 pm and 7 pm for 6 and 7:30 shifts.  There will be orientation and help before the shift begins.  The phonathon will be held at Balas I, which is located by Howard Cooper.  The Boosters will email the address to reps.

Website.  Cindy Blum reported on websites.  She updates the main page and suggested that reps check out the home page for the Athletic Department.  She also has put in a number of links, including links to schedules.  She is putting information that parents want on the web pages.  The site is www.aaps.k12.mi.us/huron.ath_dept.  She requested feedback regarding the web page.  She asked reps to encourage coaches to send in info regarding sports, coach bios, etc.  The schedules for winter sports will be posted this week.  She suggested training parents to go to the website to get info.  The coach needs to fill out a form in the athletic department with scores.  In response to a question Cindy B. explained that there is an Athletic Department website and a form website for each sport.  Some sports have an additional website.  If they have a website it is linked from the athletic dept website. 

Spirit Shop.  Nothing new regarding the Spirit Shop. There is a catalog in the Athletic office and in the Spirit Shop.

Athletic Director Report.  Shelley Vollmar gave the AD report.  Bill Blakemore is at the District mens soccer game.  She added congratulations from the athletic department for the Womens Tennis Team.  The signage is beautiful and the AD office is very happy with the new signs.  Shelley V. read the schedule of banquet dates for fall sports.  If the banquet is held at Huron the reps or coaches need to go through Crystal and Connie Goodman at 734-997-1900 ext. 502 to be sure to schedule the banquet and cafeteria.  Also, the date, time and location need to be given to Mel in the AD office, and to Crystal in the finance dept.  The Boosters will transfer $2 per player and a minimum of $50 to each sport upon completion of a form requesting reimbursement for a banquet on site at Huron and submission of the form to the Treasurer, Ruth Sauve.  Shelley V. reported that a rep from McNish was at Huron and asked that she let the reps know that McNish sells Huron apparel.  Shelley V. reported that the Executive Board has voted to get a mascot costume.  Shelley Vollmar is taking the lead.  She has checked around and the price is pretty much the same.  H. Miler reported that the price will be approximately $3900 for a character head with a cooling fan, and a cold vest and cold collar.  The costume has a useful life of 6-7 years.  The long-range plan is to for a student to be the mascot.  Helen M. advised that fund-raising will be done for the costume.  Donations of about $1000 and $300 have been tentatively committed.  She suggested that the Boosters General Membership vote to provide approximately $2000 and that fund-raising be conducted for the rest of the funds. There will be input into the costume design from the coaches and AD dept.  Discussions continued about input.  Suggestion was made to get student input.  Helen Miller reported that she is working with the Students'Class presidents and she is meeting with Mr. Edmundson regarding athletic scholarships.  Shelley and Helen M. are meeting on a variety of topics and they will follow-up regarding student input.   

Upon motion and second the General Membership approved $2000 from the Boosters general funds for the mascot costume.   Helen M. reported on the new signs installed at Huron.  We have received positive comments from Dr. Williams.  The coaches began talking about signs in the middle of August and the signs were installed in October.  Dr. Williams commented that this is the quickest that something has been done since he has been at Huron.

Old Business:  Helen M. reported on support for teams.  There were two state tournaments and the need for an expensive piece of equipment for water polo.  The menÂs and womenÂs teams came to the Boosters Executive Board and asked for a cost share.  The Executive Board voted to approve support for these teams-$600 to each team.  These teams are active members of the Boosters.  Helen M. reported that the Board looked at the issue and decided to put together criteria to evaluate request for support from the general funds.  She distributed the criteria in draft form and asked reps to look at the criteria and to provide her with comments via email or phone.  She reported that the AD dept is planning a coaches clinic and leadership forum in December/January and the plan is let team reps and coaches know about the funds available to teams from the general funds.  The goal is to make a workable process to ask for funds and evaluate the requests.  She closed by noting that she and the Executive Board welcome comments.  

Old Business:  Dave Hutchinson gave a brief report on Superball.  Ruth S. reported on the availability of funds for coaches clinics and training from the AD dept account rather than the teams' funds. She urged the coaches to talk to Bill and to look into funding for coaches training at clinics.  Shelley V. and Helen M. agreed to add the funding for coaches clinics to the list of topics they will discuss.

The Booster Club Meeting was adjourned at 8:55 pm.

Respectfully submitted by Cindy Wisner

----- Original Message -----
From: Helen Miller <hlmiller@UTKUX.UTCC.UTK.EDU>
To: <GENE-ARRAYS@ITSSRV1.UCSF.EDU>
Sent: Friday, July 07, 2000 5:34 AM
Subject: Re: slide centrifuge

> We have tried using a salad spinner ($4 at Kmart) with some success though
> it still leaves a film, probably from the "sticky" hyb solution. But
> maybe if there were the EtOH dip, mentioned earlier, before spinning . . ?
> Helen Miller Keith Goldstein
> ORNL Univ. of Tennessee
>
> On Thu, 6 Jul 2000, Chris Seidel wrote:
> >>for those of us not well versed in slide centifugation, could you post
> >>details onapparatus used thanks
> >>
> >>Ezra S Abrams, Ph.D
> >>MicroArray Chemistry
> >>Mosaic Technologies
> >>Waltham MA, 02451
> >>email: ezra@mostek.com
> >
> >The method I'm familiar with is something of a hack. One simply finds
> >a centrifuge that is capable of spinning micro-titer plates, and
> >instead of using it to spin plates, you can use it to spin slide
> >racks. The slide racks are the same ones used for washing slides.
> >They must fit into the plate holders, they must hold the slides
> >securely (some of the slide racks I've seen are slightly bowed and
> >it's easy for the slides to come out unless the sides of the rack are
> >bent in slightly to hold the slides securely). Make sure to balance
> >the rack with an opposing rack. Spin at low speed (approx 500 RPM) -
> >it's just fast enough to spin off the liquid, but not fast enough to
> >break the slides or cause enough force to do anything damaging.
> >
> >(as a side note it reminds me of a restaurant I worked in where we
> >washed the lettuce by soaking it in water, then throwing it into the
> >center of a table clothe, going out back and holding the corners of
> >the table cloth and spinning it about the head as fast as one could
> >so that all the water would go flying off. One could probably do the
> >same for slides with a hand held sling - I've considered this because
> >we actually don't have a centrifuge in our lab and the one I use
> >resides behind a locked door).
> >
> >-Chris Seidel
> >
> >Dept of MCB YGD - simple yeast gene database
> >UC Berkeley * Kane Lab http://www.phaget4.org/YGD/
> >
>
